00023 namespace GeographicLib {
00024 
00025   /**
00026    * \brief Convert between degrees and %DMS representation.
00027    *
00028    * Parse a string representing degree, minutes, and seconds and return the
00029    * angle in degrees and format an angle in degrees as degree, minutes, and
00030    * seconds.  In addition, handle NANs and infinities on input and output.
00031    **********************************************************************/
00032   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT DMS {
00033   private:
00034     typedef Math::real real;
00035     static int lookup(const std::string& s, char c) throw() {
00036       std::string::size_type r = s.find(toupper(c));
00037       return r == std::string::npos ? -1 : int(r);
00038     }
00039     template<typename T> static std::string str(T x) {
00040       std::ostringstream s; s << x; return s.str();
00041     }
00042     static const std::string hemispheres_;
00043     static const std::string signs_;
00044     static const std::string digits_;
00045     static const std::string dmsindicators_;
00046     static const std::string components_[3];
00047     static Math::real NumMatch(const std::string& s);
00048     DMS();                      // Disable constructor
00049 
00050   public:
00051 
00052     /**
00053      * Indicator for presence of hemisphere indicator (N/S/E/W) on latitudes
00054      * and longitudes.
00055      **********************************************************************/
00056     enum flag {
00057       /**
00058        * No indicator present.
00059        * @hideinitializer
00060        **********************************************************************/
00061       NONE = 0,
00062       /**
00063        * Latitude indicator (N/S) present.
00064        * @hideinitializer
00065        **********************************************************************/
00066       LATITUDE = 1,
00067       /**
00068        * Longitude indicator (E/W) present.
00069        * @hideinitializer
00070        **********************************************************************/
00071       LONGITUDE = 2,
00072       /**
00073        * Used in Encode to indicate output of an azimuth in [000, 360) with no
00074        * letter indicator.
00075        * @hideinitializer
00076        **********************************************************************/
00077       AZIMUTH = 3,
00078       /**
00079        * Used in Encode to indicate output of a plain number.
00080        * @hideinitializer
00081        **********************************************************************/
00082       NUMBER = 4,
00083     };
00084 
00085     /**
00086      * Indicator for trailing units on an angle.
00087      **********************************************************************/
00088     enum component {
00089       /**
00090        * Trailing unit is degrees.
00091        * @hideinitializer
00092        **********************************************************************/
00093       DEGREE = 0,
00094       /**
00095        * Trailing unit is arc minutes.
00096        * @hideinitializer
00097        **********************************************************************/
00098       MINUTE = 1,
00099       /**
00100        * Trailing unit is arc seconds.
00101        * @hideinitializer
00102        **********************************************************************/
00103       SECOND = 2,
00104     };
00105 
00106     /**
00107      * Convert a string in DMS to an angle.
00108      *
00109      * @param[in] dms string input.
00110      * @param[out] ind a DMS::flag value indicating the presence of a
00111      *   hemisphere indicator.
00112      * @return angle (degrees).
00113      *
00114      * Degrees, minutes, and seconds are indicated by the letters d, ', &quot;,
00115      * and these components_ may only be given in this order.  Any (but not all)
00116      * components_ may be omitted.  The last component indicator may be omitted
00117      * and is assumed to be tbe next smallest unit (thus 33d10 is interpreted
00118      * as 33d10').  The final component may be a decimal fraction but the
00119      * non-final components_ must be integers.  The integer parts of the minutes
00120      * and seconds components_ must be less than 60.  A single leading sign is
00121      * permitted.  A hemisphere designator (N, E, W, S) may be added to tbe
00122      * beginning or end of the string.  The result is multiplied by the implied
00123      * signed of the hemisphere designator (negative for S and W).  In addition
00124      * \e ind is set to DMS::LATITUDE if N or S is present, to DMS::LONGITUDE
00125      * if E or W is present, and to DMS::NONE otherwise.  Throws an error on a
00126      * malformed string.  No check is performed on the range of the result.
00127      **********************************************************************/
00128     static Math::real Decode(const std::string& dms, flag& ind);
00129 
00130     /**
00131      * Convert DMS to an angle.
00132      *
00133      * @param[in] d degrees.
00134      * @param[in] m arc minutes.
00135      * @param[in] s arc seconds.
00136      * @return angle (degrees)
00137      *
00138      * This does not propagate the sign on \e d to the other components_, so
00139      * -3d20' would need to be represented as - DMS::Decode(3.0, 20.0) or
00140      * DMS::Decode(-3.0, -20.0).
00141      **********************************************************************/
00142     static Math::real Decode(real d, real m = 0, real s = 0) throw()
00143     { return d + (m + s/real(60))/real(60); }
00144 
00145     /**
00146      * Convert a string to a real number.
00147      *
00148      * @param[in] str string input.
00149      * @return decoded number.
00150      **********************************************************************/
00151     static Math::real Decode(const std::string& str);
00152 
00153     /**
00154      * Convert a pair of strings to latitude and longitude.
00155      *
00156      * @param[in] dmsa first string.
00157      * @param[in] dmsb second string.
00158      * @param[out] lat latitude.
00159      * @param[out] lon longitude.
00160      *
00161      * By default, the \e lat (resp., \e lon) is assigned to the results of
00162      * decoding \e dmsa (resp., \e dmsb).  However this is overridden if either
00163      * \e dmsa or \e dmsb contain a latitude or longitude hemisphere designator
00164      * (N, S, E, W).  Throws an error if the decoded numbers are out of the
00165      * ranges [-90<sup>o</sup>, 90<sup>o</sup>] for latitude and
00166      * [-180<sup>o</sup>, 360<sup>o</sup>] for longitude and, in which case \e
00167      * lat and \e lon are unchanged.  Finally the longitude is reduced to the
00168      * range [-180<sup>o</sup>, 180<sup>o</sup>).
00169      **********************************************************************/
00170     static void DecodeLatLon(const std::string& dmsa, const std::string& dmsb,
00171                              real& lat, real& lon);
00172 
00173     /**
00174      * Convert a string to an angle in degrees.
00175      *
00176      * @param[in] angstr input string.
00177      * @return angle (degrees)
00178      *
00179      * No hemisphere designator is allowed and no check is done on the range of
00180      * the result.
00181      **********************************************************************/
00182     static Math::real DecodeAngle(const std::string& angstr);
00183 
00184     /**
00185      * Convert a string to an azimuth in degrees.
00186      *
00187      * @param[in] azistr input string.
00188      * @return azimuth (degrees)
00189      *
00190      * A hemisphere designator E/W can be used; the result is multiplied by -1
00191      * if W is present.  Throws an error if the result is out of the range
00192      * [-180<sup>o</sup>, 360<sup>o</sup>].  Finally the azimuth is reduced to
00193      * the range [-180<sup>o</sup>, 180<sup>o</sup>).
00194      **********************************************************************/
00195     static Math::real DecodeAzimuth(const std::string& azistr);
00196 
00197     /**
00198      * Convert angle (in degrees) into a DMS string.
00199      *
00200      * @param[in] angle input angle (degrees)
00201      * @param[in] trailing DMS::component value indicating the trailing units
00202      *   on the string and this is given as a decimal number if necessary.
00203      * @param[in] prec the number of digits_ after the decimal point for the
00204      *   trailing component.
00205      * @param[in] ind DMS::flag value indicated additional formatting.
00206      * @return formatted string
00207      *
00208      * The interpretation of \e ind is as follows:
00209      * - ind == DMS::NONE, signed result no leading zeros on degrees except in
00210      *   the units place, e.g., -8d03'.
00211      * - ind == DMS::LATITUDE, trailing N or S hemisphere designator, no sign,
00212      *   pad degrees to 2 digits_, e.g., 08d03'S.
00213      * - ind == DMS::LONGITUDE, trailing E or W hemisphere designator, no
00214      *   sign, pad degrees to 3 digits_, e.g., 008d03'W.
00215      * - ind == DMS::AZIMUTH, convert to the range [0, 360<sup>o</sup>), no
00216      *   sign, pad degrees to 3 digits_, , e.g., 351d57'.
00217      * .
00218      * The integer parts of the minutes and seconds components_ are always given
00219      * with 2 digits_.
00220      **********************************************************************/
00221     static std::string Encode(real angle, component trailing, unsigned prec,
00222                               flag ind = NONE);
00223 
00224     /**
00225      * Convert angle into a DMS string selecting the trailing component
00226      * based on the precision.
00227      *
00228      * @param[in] angle input angle (degrees)
00229      * @param[in] prec the precision relative to 1 degree.
00230      * @param[in] ind DMS::flag value indicated additional formatting.
00231      * @return formatted string
00232      *
00233      * \e prec indicates the precision relative to 1 degree, e.g., \e prec = 3
00234      * gives a result accurate to 0.1' and \e prec = 4 gives a result accurate
00235      * to 1&quot;.  \e ind is interpreted as in DMS::Encode with the additional
00236      * facility at DMS::NUMBER treats \e angle a number in fixed format with
00237      * precision \e prec.
00238      **********************************************************************/
00239     static std::string Encode(real angle, unsigned prec, flag ind = NONE) {
00240       if (ind == NUMBER) {
00241         if (!Math::isfinite(angle))
00242           return angle < 0 ? std::string("-inf") :
00243             (angle > 0 ? std::string("inf") : std::string("nan"));
00244         std::ostringstream s;
00245         s << std::fixed << std::setprecision(prec) << angle;
00246         return s.str();
00247       } else
00248         return Encode(angle,
00249                       prec < 2 ? DEGREE : (prec < 4 ? MINUTE : SECOND),
00250                       prec < 2 ? prec : (prec < 4 ? prec - 2 : prec - 4),
00251                       ind);
00252     }
00253 
00254     /**
00255      * Split angle into degrees and mintues
00256      *
00257      * @param[in] ang angle (degrees)
00258      * @param[out] d degrees (an integer returned as a real)
00259      * @param[out] m arc minutes.
00260      **********************************************************************/
00261     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m) throw() {
00262       d = int(ang); m = 60 * (ang - d);
00263     }
00264 
00265     /**
00266      * Split angle into degrees and mintues and seconds.
00267      *
00268      * @param[in] ang angle (degrees)
00269      * @param[out] d degrees (an integer returned as a real)
00270      * @param[out] m arc minutes (an integer returned as a real)
00271      * @param[out] s arc seconds.
00272      **********************************************************************/
00273     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m, real& s) throw() {
00274       d = int(ang); ang = 60 * (ang - d);
00275       m = int(ang); s = 60 * (ang - m);
00276     }
00277 
00278   };
00279 
00280 } // namespace GeographicLib
